ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read true economic papers and improved my approach to research questions and assignments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that the discussions work well but believe that more structure would have improved the course. Perhaps assigning half the class to debate one side of an argument and the other half to support the other side. Or asking students to lead the discussions for each paper assigned could create more engagement. I think that Professor Zhao was incredibly helpful with the research assignment and helping me to improve my approach. I also appreciated the mini lectures and thought that they provided important context.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely recommend this class for anyone who is interested in a rigorous introduction to the economic challenges that China (and developing nations like it) faces. Professor Zhao is devoted to students' learning, and give clear feedbacks to all written assignments and research proposals. For someone interested in economics grad school like me, the class was an excellent opportunity to build a solid foundation for understanding China and to think up my own original research questions. My final project turns out to be something that I'm genuinely interested in, and I look forward to actually implementing it in the near future.
